pullRequest.body:
This can be used to hide long proofs in the statement of a theorem behind an auxiliary lemma.

Co-authored-by: Sven Manthe sven.manthe@uni-bonn.de

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [9e66e72292](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22296/commits/9e66e72292170b47247ada6bcb14722108c55fa8)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic | 2596 | 2598 | +2 (+0.08%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Tactic`|2|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.Abstract` (new file)|21|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ bar`
`+ baz`
`+ foo`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

It would be nicer if the generated name was more robust. For example you could use ``mkAuxName ((← getDeclName?).get! ++ `abstract) 1``.

Also the `get!` looks a bit dodgy, but it might be fine.
Can you add a test showing that when `tacs` doesn't close the goal, `abstract tacs` gives the same error message as `tacs`?
We want to support multiple `abstract` calls in the same lemma statement. I guess we could use the smallest number where the lemma doesn't exist yet?
Yes, `mkAuxName` keeps incrementing the given number (1) until it gives a name that isn't taken yet.
It may also be good to add the file to the list of ignored imports in noshake. Because I'm guessing shake will not recognize that the import of `abstract` is required.
Thanks for the useful review comments! In the previous version `abstract` would just raise an error if there were unsolved goals.
I changed it so that in case of error, it keeps the tactic state, instead of resetting what the tactic goals are.

The following example with universe levels gives unintuitive behaviour:
```
def fooo : Function.const (∀ α : Type _, ∀ a : α, a = a) 1 (by abstract simp) = 1 := rfl
#print fooo
```
The tactic thinks that it failed, since `newGoal.hasMVar` returned `true` (there is a universe metaviarable). But in the end the declaration compiles correctly (without any abstracting happening) because Lean replaces universe metavariables with universe parameters after elaborating the theorem statement. This example is solved by replacing `newGoal.hasMVar` with `newGoal.hasExprMVar`. Are you happy to make this change?

I have fixed it now, allowing universe metavariables in the abstracted term. Additionally, in the failure case I made the tactic explicitly throw an error to avoid any more above mentioned confusing behaviour where the tactic succeeds without actually abstracting the term.
I think this is ready now @eric-wieser
Is this the same as `as_aux_lemma => tacSeq` which was added last month?
Oh, well spotted, In that case this PR is redundant.
Yes, this seems superfluous now.
Can you add a test where the extracted theorem needs universe variables? Bonus points if the proof needs one that the rest of the statement doesn't .

pullRequest.title: feat: abstract tactic

It may also be good to add the file to the list of ignored imports in noshake. Because I'm guessing shake will not recognize that the import of `abstract` is required.

source.title: perf: avoid proofs on rhs of simp lemmas

nodes.body: Thanks for the useful review comments! In the previous version `abstract` would just raise an error if there were unsolved goals.
I changed it so that in case of error, it keeps the tactic state, instead of resetting what the tactic goals are.

The following example with universe levels gives unintuitive behaviour:
```
def fooo : Function.const (∀ α : Type _, ∀ a : α, a = a) 1 (by abstract simp) = 1 := rfl
#print fooo
```
The tactic thinks that it failed, since `newGoal.hasMVar` returned `true` (there is a universe metaviarable). But in the end the declaration compiles correctly (without any abstracting happening) because Lean replaces universe metavariables with universe parameters after elaborating the theorem statement. This example is solved by replacing `newGoal.hasMVar` with `newGoal.hasExprMVar`. Are you happy to make this change?

I have fixed it now, allowing universe metavariables in the abstracted term. Additionally, in the failure case I made the tactic explicitly throw an error to avoid any more above mentioned confusing behaviour where the tactic succeeds without actually abstracting the term.
I think this is ready now @eric-wieser
Is this the same as `as_aux_lemma => tacSeq` which was added last month?
Oh, well spotted, In that case this PR is redundant.
Yes, this seems superfluous now.
